--- Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> Tyler Streeter wrote:
> 
> >>...unless you were intending to
> >>transfer the whole 
> >>project to a real-world scenario I see eye
> >>simulation as unnecessary.
> >>    
> >>
> >
> >I'm reading the book Evolutionary Robotics right
> now
> >which focuses heavily on using senses robots could
> >actually use.  My mind is kind of geared in that
> >direction at present.  I guess I would like to
> leave
> >that option (transferring neural nets to real
> robots)
> >open, so I am trying to focus on more realistic
> >senses.  
> >
> >  
> >
> Hi Tyler,
> 
> My concern though is that you are allowing the scope
> of your project to 
> increase and encompass a lot more than can be
> achieved in one go. The 
> stuff being discussed on this group about fitness
> functions and the type 
> of senses needed is all good stuff and represents a
> significant problem 
> and interesting piece of research in itself. By
> adding the extra factors 
> of ray tracing and image analysis you are
> dramatically increasing the 
> complexity of the problem. Image analysis by itself
> is a long-standing 
> branch of research AKAIK and I'm just thinking about
> detecting lines and 
> objects in 2D images, in order to build a 3D model
> in your head you have 
> to combine two 2D images (stereoscopic), you could
> do this with code 
> rather than in the NN's but it is CPU intensive work
> especially if you 
> include the ray tracing!
> 
> Scope creep is the death of many a project. My
> advice would be to keep 
> your scope focused and you can move on to the other
> stuff with a new 
> project later.
> 
> Hope I didn't come across as *too* much like a
> nay-sayer there :)

Nope, not at all.  I definitely need to keep things
simple, especially at first.  One thing I'm interested
in is figuring out these different problems and trying
to combine them into a single agent.  I'll be sure to
keep the search space size in check.

Tyler
